reasoning: The critique targets a real inferential step in §2.1–2.3: using historical moral error and contemporary moral disagreement as evidence that “mostly-great” futures are unlikely by default. That step is relevant to the paper’s overall case for “no easy eutopia,” but it is only one pillar among others (e.g., the multiplicative/product model and the later technical discussion of bounded/unbounded/fussy value functions), so centrality is moderate rather than high. The critique moderately weakens the targeted inference by correctly noting that possibility-of-failure and plural moral condemnation don’t, by themselves, yield a probability claim about default futures without an additional model/bridge. However, it’s somewhat generic and doesn’t engage with the paper’s attempts at such a bridge (e.g., the multiplicative fragility toy model, fat-tailed considerations), so it doesn’t strongly refute the position. The claims it makes are largely correct, though slightly overstated in portraying that inference as the central one. It is clear, focused, and contains little to no dead weight.
title: Moral fallibility doesn't establish that good futures are improbable
